description: The Implementing an Advanced Server Infrastructure exam is the second of two exams required to obtain the Microsoft Certified Solutions Expert (MCSE) certification and shows one knows how to manage and maintain a server infrastructure and implement a data center according to Microsoftâ€™s best practices. This exam moves into significantly more complex topics and configurations than those covered in the previous examinations. The topics covered range from high availability to identity and access solutions. The typical viewer would be anyone operating as a senior systems administrator in a large or enterprise level business and also focuses on.
name: MCSE Windows Server 2012 - 70-414
subtitle: Implementing an Advanced Server Infrastructure

episodes.description: The Implementing an Advanced Server Infrastructure exam is the second of two exams required to obtain the Microsoft Certified Solutions Expert (MCSE) certification. This exam moves into significantly more complex topics and configurations than those covered in the previous examinations. The topics covered range from high availability to identity and access solutions. The typical viewer would be anyone operating as a senior systems administrator in a large or enterprise level business.
episodes.title: Overview of MCSE Windows Server 2012 (70-414)
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,006 --> 00:00:06,105
[SOUND] The 70-414 exam
is the final step for

2
00:00:06,105 --> 00:00:12,056
candidates that are looking
to achieve the MCSE

3
00:00:12,056 --> 00:00:17,275
server infrastructure certification.

4
00:00:17,275 --> 00:00:18,885
It's a long road.

5
00:00:18,885 --> 00:00:20,320
>> Mm-hm.
>> There's a lot of stuff that you gotta

6
00:00:20,320 --> 00:00:21,540
learn along the way.

7
00:00:21,540 --> 00:00:22,900
And this is kinda the end.

8
00:00:22,900 --> 00:00:26,220
So let's take a minute and
just look at what this entails, and

9
00:00:26,220 --> 00:00:27,530
let's start really high level.

10
00:00:27,530 --> 00:00:29,100
By the time you've gotten to this point,

11
00:00:29,100 --> 00:00:33,250
you more than likely know what
the MCSE server infrastructure is.

12
00:00:33,250 --> 00:00:36,050
But let's just take a glance at it
real quick, do a quick overview, and

13
00:00:36,050 --> 00:00:39,800
then we'll dive into exactly what
this exam and certification entail.

14
00:00:39,800 --> 00:00:41,002
>> Cool.

15
00:00:41,002 --> 00:00:45,930
All right now the MCSE server
infrastructure it actually starts out

16
00:00:45,930 --> 00:00:48,220
as the MCSA server infrastructure.

17
00:00:48,220 --> 00:00:52,551
So, by the time you're at this point, you
should have already completed the 7410,

18
00:00:52,551 --> 00:00:56,830
411 and 412 examinations,
once you've achieved those,

19
00:00:56,830 --> 00:01:00,430
you get the MCSA Server
Administrator Certification.

20
00:01:00,430 --> 00:01:03,860
It's the Microsoft Certified
Solutions Associate.

21
00:01:03,860 --> 00:01:05,777
That's MCSA.
>> I love the way that they changed

22
00:01:05,777 --> 00:01:07,700
the name, and left the acronym the same.

23
00:01:07,700 --> 00:01:09,794
It's a really good for all of us,] right?

24
00:01:09,794 --> 00:01:12,391
>> It's a lot better than the way
it used to be, you know, for

25
00:01:12,391 --> 00:01:16,190
a little while it became the MCTS, and
the MCITP, and everyone hated that.

26
00:01:16,190 --> 00:01:19,660
So at least it's back to the original
acronyms that people like.

27
00:01:19,660 --> 00:01:23,735
You should already have your MCSA
before moving into the MCSE.

28
00:01:23,735 --> 00:01:24,270
>> Mm-hm.

29
00:01:24,270 --> 00:01:25,540
>> Right?
It kinda goes without saying.

30
00:01:25,540 --> 00:01:28,040
>> Yep.
>> And the main reason is the MCSA

31
00:01:28,040 --> 00:01:31,360
really focuses on the how to do things.

32
00:01:31,360 --> 00:01:32,920
How to implement active directory.

33
00:01:32,920 --> 00:01:34,610
How to install DNS.

34
00:01:34,610 --> 00:01:37,490
How to set up file replication services.

35
00:01:37,490 --> 00:01:39,358
How to do all these different things.

36
00:01:39,358 --> 00:01:40,530
>> Mm-hm.
>> All right.

37
00:01:40,530 --> 00:01:42,390
But you don't get the why side of it.

38
00:01:42,390 --> 00:01:42,940
Right?
And

39
00:01:42,940 --> 00:01:45,850
that's because somebody at the MCSA
level is not doing designs,

40
00:01:45,850 --> 00:01:47,550
they're doing implementation.

41
00:01:47,550 --> 00:01:48,790
>> Right.
>> They're the grunt-workers,

42
00:01:48,790 --> 00:01:51,480
the people in the field
actually making things happen,

43
00:01:51,480 --> 00:01:52,860
which is really important work.

44
00:01:52,860 --> 00:01:53,680
>> Right.
>> Don't let me

45
00:01:53,680 --> 00:01:55,520
sound like that's not important.

46
00:01:55,520 --> 00:01:58,720
What they do is extremely important, but

47
00:01:58,720 --> 00:02:02,650
somebody has to be behind the scenes
governing our overall design.

48
00:02:02,650 --> 00:02:03,960
>> Right.

49
00:02:03,960 --> 00:02:06,100
And that's when the MCSE comes in.

50
00:02:06,100 --> 00:02:11,210
Whoever has that role,
the Microsoft Certified Solutions Expert,

51
00:02:11,210 --> 00:02:15,160
they're the person that's coming up with
the overall, the big picture, all right?

52
00:02:15,160 --> 00:02:17,380
Not necessarily going into the field and
doing the work.

53
00:02:17,380 --> 00:02:20,530
Now, you need to already have that
experience because how do you a design if

54
00:02:20,530 --> 00:02:22,760
you don't know how something works.

55
00:02:22,760 --> 00:02:24,530
But they need to understand the why.

56
00:02:25,630 --> 00:02:30,200
And at this point, you also should
have completed the 7413 exam,

57
00:02:30,200 --> 00:02:34,730
which was the first one that really
dived straight into designing and

58
00:02:34,730 --> 00:02:36,910
implementing a server infrastructure.

59
00:02:36,910 --> 00:02:41,510
We rehash all of the things in 410,
411, and 412.

60
00:02:41,510 --> 00:02:46,360
Right here on 413 we're looking at the why
you do these things why you might need

61
00:02:46,360 --> 00:02:49,730
five servers as opposed to four servers
where you would put those servers in

62
00:02:49,730 --> 00:02:50,340
the global design.

63
00:02:52,340 --> 00:02:56,890
That leads us to the last one which is
7414 the show that we're getting prepared

64
00:02:56,890 --> 00:03:00,800
for right here with
this one we dive not so

65
00:03:00,800 --> 00:03:06,410
much into the why of our server
infrastructure but how we manage and

66
00:03:06,410 --> 00:03:10,140
maintain that server infrastructure,
how you keep your data center operational?

67
00:03:10,140 --> 00:03:12,970
And it really does build
around the data center.

68
00:03:12,970 --> 00:03:14,870
We kind of put workstations
out of our mind.

69
00:03:14,870 --> 00:03:17,270
Any workstation stuff on this one?

70
00:03:17,270 --> 00:03:18,290
>> I don't think so at all.

71
00:03:18,290 --> 00:03:21,430
Really in your SAs,
you're learning how to monitor and

72
00:03:21,430 --> 00:03:23,880
manage your individual
servers you're setting up.

73
00:03:23,880 --> 00:03:27,110
You're the DHCP admin or that DNS admin.

74
00:03:27,110 --> 00:03:30,870
Now you're talking about monitoring your
whole solution, and your data center, and

75
00:03:30,870 --> 00:03:34,100
your virtual machine infrastructure and
all of that.

76
00:03:34,100 --> 00:03:37,350
>> So whenever it comes to monitoring
these days the Microsoft monitoring

77
00:03:37,350 --> 00:03:40,270
managing, they have their
system center suite.

78
00:03:40,270 --> 00:03:42,980
And so what we're gonna do is
look at if you're running your

79
00:03:42,980 --> 00:03:45,560
own data center even if its
cloud data center right.

80
00:03:45,560 --> 00:03:47,830
You tied a Windows Azure or whatever.

81
00:03:47,830 --> 00:03:50,290
You need to monitor and
manage those systems and

82
00:03:50,290 --> 00:03:53,660
there are a number of system center
solutions that deal with that.

83
00:03:53,660 --> 00:03:55,210
And that's what we're
gonna take a look at.

84
00:03:55,210 --> 00:03:58,880
The general best practices for
how you should be running your environment

85
00:03:58,880 --> 00:04:02,440
as well as the tools from
Microsoft that you can use.

86
00:04:02,440 --> 00:04:04,230
Right?
You don't have to in real life.

87
00:04:04,230 --> 00:04:05,230
You can use whatever you want.

88
00:04:05,230 --> 00:04:08,740
But if you wanna pass this exam you
need to know the system center stuff.

89
00:04:08,740 --> 00:04:12,380
So we're kinda shifting and
that's why this one was designing and

90
00:04:12,380 --> 00:04:14,280
this one is just implementing.

91
00:04:14,280 --> 00:04:15,750
Right?
Implementing in advanced server

92
00:04:15,750 --> 00:04:19,541
infrastructure because we're gonna see,
we are going to see a lot of design,

93
00:04:19,541 --> 00:04:21,440
we'll get to that with
the exam objectives.

94
00:04:21,440 --> 00:04:25,500
It is focused more on what
you need to put in place to

95
00:04:25,500 --> 00:04:30,460
keep your data center running nice and
smooth and keep an eye on it.

96
00:04:30,460 --> 00:04:34,730
When you've completed that fifth exam,
you'll be awarded the MCSE,

97
00:04:34,730 --> 00:04:37,090
the Microsoft Certified Solutions Expert.

98
00:04:37,090 --> 00:04:42,790
And that will designate that you are an
expert, that you know how to implement

99
00:04:42,790 --> 00:04:45,700
a data center according to
Microsoft's best practices, right,

100
00:04:45,700 --> 00:04:46,790
a server infrastructure.

101
00:04:46,790 --> 00:04:50,780
All right, so
let's take a look at the exam itself.

102
00:04:50,780 --> 00:04:53,340
All right.
If I jump over here to the 7414

103
00:04:53,340 --> 00:04:54,250
exam, it's $150.

104
00:04:54,250 --> 00:04:55,060
Right?

105
00:04:55,060 --> 00:04:57,720
Microsoft exams are really reasonably

106
00:04:57,720 --> 00:05:00,340
priced compared to other
vendors these days.

107
00:05:00,340 --> 00:05:02,380
Although you do have to
take a lot of the exams.

108
00:05:02,380 --> 00:05:04,880
>> And then again every three years or
something.

109
00:05:04,880 --> 00:05:06,170
So they get their money.

110
00:05:06,170 --> 00:05:08,919
>> Yep.
So we do have a new exam, 70-414.

111
00:05:08,919 --> 00:05:10,170
It's $150.00 to take it.

112
00:05:10,170 --> 00:05:14,090
You can take it at any
Pearson View Center.

113
00:05:15,590 --> 00:05:19,970
Right today, while we're taping this,
you can still take the exam at Sylvan for

114
00:05:19,970 --> 00:05:21,010
Metrics Centers also.

115
00:05:22,010 --> 00:05:26,790
That ends, I think they make a note of
that right here, yeah, January 1st, 2015.

116
00:05:26,790 --> 00:05:30,350
So, if you're watching this
January 1st 2015 or later,

117
00:05:30,350 --> 00:05:32,750
which is only, two months away.

118
00:05:32,750 --> 00:05:36,230
Then, after that point, you won't be able
to take it at Prometric anymore, right?

119
00:05:36,230 --> 00:05:39,260
So you'll need to take it at view, and

120
00:05:39,260 --> 00:05:42,341
I would just plan on taking
it at view right now.

121
00:05:42,341 --> 00:05:43,930
>> Yea, and
you look at there where it says,

122
00:05:43,930 --> 00:05:47,700
I think with Prometric it takes five
to seven business days I think.

123
00:05:47,700 --> 00:05:48,610
So they're just not.

124
00:05:49,690 --> 00:05:53,000
Very quick with that stuff or Pearson VUE
you can find out that day or the next day,

125
00:05:54,040 --> 00:05:58,480
and get your transcript updated,
things like that.

126
00:05:58,480 --> 00:06:02,120
>> You'll always find your pass or fail
score right at the end of the exam, so

127
00:06:02,120 --> 00:06:02,990
they do that.

128
00:06:02,990 --> 00:06:04,090
What Mike's talking about is they

129
00:06:04,090 --> 00:06:05,970
have to get that information
back to Microsoft, right.

130
00:06:05,970 --> 00:06:09,022
And yeah,
that's what's pretty bad about that.

131
00:06:09,022 --> 00:06:11,450
All right, so
that's why we see both of them here, but

132
00:06:11,450 --> 00:06:15,010
if I were you I would just plan on view
and not worry about the record so much.

133
00:06:15,010 --> 00:06:17,720
All right, so that's the exam cost.

134
00:06:17,720 --> 00:06:21,840
They give you some basic information but
they aren't really detailed about things

135
00:06:21,840 --> 00:06:27,270
like how many questions you have and
what's the passing score, and so on.

136
00:06:27,270 --> 00:06:30,900
That's because Microsoft does
these performance based exams, and

137
00:06:30,900 --> 00:06:34,587
that means you could have several
different amounts of questions.

138
00:06:34,587 --> 00:06:37,560
So, Mike, you and I could go and
take this exam right now and

139
00:06:37,560 --> 00:06:39,820
I might have 50 more questions than you.

140
00:06:39,820 --> 00:06:42,200
That doesn't mean that
Mike got an easier exam,

141
00:06:42,200 --> 00:06:46,980
just means maybe you got
more simulations that I did.

142
00:06:46,980 --> 00:06:48,210
>> Right.
An old, drag and drop,

143
00:06:48,210 --> 00:06:50,760
put them in place type questions,
things like that.

144
00:06:50,760 --> 00:06:53,860
>> And they do full, it's not flash based.

145
00:06:53,860 --> 00:06:56,010
I forget what they built it on.

146
00:06:56,010 --> 00:06:56,950
Probably silverlight.

147
00:06:56,950 --> 00:07:01,535
They do these imbedded plug ins that
actually give you a fake Windows UI so

148
00:07:01,535 --> 00:07:03,585
you can go through and
configure some things.

149
00:07:03,585 --> 00:07:05,235
They're awkward and I
>> They are.

150
00:07:05,235 --> 00:07:06,004
>> But they're in there.

151
00:07:06,004 --> 00:07:07,975
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's supposed to show that you actually

152
00:07:07,975 --> 00:07:09,185
have that experience.

153
00:07:09,185 --> 00:07:12,810
On a design exam, though,
one like this you're gonna have a lot more

154
00:07:12,810 --> 00:07:17,020
word problems, a lot of where
they describe an environment and

155
00:07:17,020 --> 00:07:19,080
you make recommended changes
based on your knowledge.

156
00:07:19,080 --> 00:07:20,950
>> Yeah, bring your reading
glasses if you need them.

157
00:07:20,950 --> 00:07:23,720
It's like reading an essay in there and
then going back and

158
00:07:23,720 --> 00:07:26,115
answering ten questions on
this essay they've given you.

159
00:07:26,115 --> 00:07:27,650
Mm-hm.

160
00:07:27,650 --> 00:07:31,770
All right, so some of the other things we
need to know, the exam objectives, right?

161
00:07:31,770 --> 00:07:35,720
This one covers what doesn't look
like all that much in the beginning.

162
00:07:35,720 --> 00:07:38,790
Really just four objectives,
nice and small.

163
00:07:38,790 --> 00:07:41,370
We've got manage and
maintain a server infrastructure.

164
00:07:41,370 --> 00:07:44,870
And notice how each of these
are listed as 25 to 30%.

165
00:07:44,870 --> 00:07:46,310
Except the last one's 20 to 25%.

166
00:07:46,310 --> 00:07:51,270
So the exam's pretty evenly
divided across these four.

167
00:07:51,270 --> 00:07:53,660
And the first one is just straight
up server infrastructure.

168
00:07:53,660 --> 00:07:57,160
So we're talking about, you've got
a data center, you've got servers,

169
00:07:57,160 --> 00:07:59,610
you've got physical servers and
virtual servers.

170
00:07:59,610 --> 00:08:02,440
We need to maintain that infrastructure.

171
00:08:02,440 --> 00:08:06,700
And if we break that out you'll see they
break it down into quite a few things,

172
00:08:06,700 --> 00:08:08,170
starting with an administrative model.

173
00:08:08,170 --> 00:08:12,070
Right?
Administrative models are how we

174
00:08:12,070 --> 00:08:12,990
implement management.

175
00:08:12,990 --> 00:08:15,110
Is it just one person,
is it multiple people,

176
00:08:15,110 --> 00:08:16,720
do people have different levels of access?

177
00:08:16,720 --> 00:08:19,519
Those are all different things we think
about in our administrative model.

178
00:08:21,410 --> 00:08:23,280
Then we've got our
monitoring strategy right?

179
00:08:23,280 --> 00:08:24,348
How are we going to monitor this.

180
00:08:24,348 --> 00:08:27,500
If a server fails, if an issue happens,
how do we get information?

181
00:08:27,500 --> 00:08:30,460
If we're troubleshooting what historical
data do we have to collect to be able

182
00:08:30,460 --> 00:08:33,150
to look at and what tools and
resources are available to us?

183
00:08:33,150 --> 00:08:35,760
And that's when we start introducing
the viewers into System Center 2012.

184
00:08:35,760 --> 00:08:38,720
And we're going to be doing
System Center 2012 R2,

185
00:08:38,720 --> 00:08:42,380
because that's what's on
the new version of the exam.

186
00:08:42,380 --> 00:08:45,070
So we'll be using that
throughout the whole show,

187
00:08:45,070 --> 00:08:49,630
but in real life, most of what's
in 2012 is the same in 2012 R2.

188
00:08:49,630 --> 00:08:53,220
But there will be a few additional
features we cover that are new in R2.

189
00:08:53,220 --> 00:08:55,800
And then we got plan and

190
00:08:55,800 --> 00:09:00,770
implement automated remediation, so when
something goes wrong, how can we fix it?

191
00:09:00,770 --> 00:09:02,330
Right?
What's our backup plan?

192
00:09:02,330 --> 00:09:04,260
And can we automate that, right?

193
00:09:04,260 --> 00:09:06,170
Can we automate taking
care of the problems, and

194
00:09:06,170 --> 00:09:08,160
getting things back up and running?

195
00:09:08,160 --> 00:09:12,920
So it's a pretty heavy topic for
just being one part of the exam.

196
00:09:14,600 --> 00:09:16,030
After that we break into plan and

197
00:09:16,030 --> 00:09:18,810
implement a highly available
enterprise infrastructure.

198
00:09:20,000 --> 00:09:22,620
A better way to deal with failures is to
>> [LAUGH]

199
00:09:22,620 --> 00:09:24,040
>> Avoid them in the first place.

200
00:09:24,040 --> 00:09:24,730
>> Exactly.
>> Right,

201
00:09:24,730 --> 00:09:28,490
so what kind of infrastructure can we put
in place to make it where failures don't

202
00:09:28,490 --> 00:09:29,750
affect our services.

203
00:09:29,750 --> 00:09:33,770
So we'll talk about clustering,
network services, network load balancing,

204
00:09:33,770 --> 00:09:34,810
and other things.

205
00:09:34,810 --> 00:09:37,600
And then we'll talk about storage,
which is a big deal.

206
00:09:37,600 --> 00:09:40,758
A lot of people don't properly plan for
storage failures.

207
00:09:40,758 --> 00:09:45,225
Then we'll take a look at other roles
that we might need to make redundant.

208
00:09:45,225 --> 00:09:48,154
And, by roles,
I mean things like DHCP, DNS,

209
00:09:48,154 --> 00:09:51,189
they mention [CROSSTALK]
>> Basic infrastructure that really keeps

210
00:09:51,189 --> 00:09:52,270
everything else running.

211
00:09:52,270 --> 00:09:55,160
>> Mm-hm.
And then lastly we've got

212
00:09:55,160 --> 00:09:59,370
a business continuity and
disaster recovery solution, all right?

213
00:09:59,370 --> 00:10:02,780
And I know it kind of sounds the same,
but business continuity,

214
00:10:02,780 --> 00:10:07,720
that means making sure that we can keep
working, even when there's a failure.

215
00:10:07,720 --> 00:10:11,100
During the failure we might not be at
full capacity, but we're still working.

216
00:10:11,100 --> 00:10:11,720
Right.
>> Huh.

217
00:10:11,720 --> 00:10:15,210
>> Disaster recovery's getting
us back to peak performance.

218
00:10:15,210 --> 00:10:15,870
>> Right.

219
00:10:15,870 --> 00:10:20,000
>> So, you know, if on a good day you're
at 100% and then a failure happens,

220
00:10:20,000 --> 00:10:21,260
instead of dropping to 0%,
>> Right

221
00:10:21,260 --> 00:10:23,660
>> Then you drop to 50% or something.

222
00:10:23,660 --> 00:10:25,530
>> Huh.
>> So you're running at half capacity.

223
00:10:25,530 --> 00:10:27,630
And then after you fix the problem
you come back up to a 100,

224
00:10:27,630 --> 00:10:31,410
so staying at that 50%,
that's business continuity.

225
00:10:31,410 --> 00:10:34,420
You're continuing to do
business during the failure,

226
00:10:34,420 --> 00:10:38,010
and after we get back up to 100%,
that's disaster recovery, we're recovered.

227
00:10:39,940 --> 00:10:43,410
That's one of those sections right
there that in, real life land.

228
00:10:43,410 --> 00:10:45,830
It's not a skill you use every day but

229
00:10:45,830 --> 00:10:47,640
on the day you do use it
>> [LAUGH]

230
00:10:47,640 --> 00:10:49,000
>> You are glad you have it.

231
00:10:49,000 --> 00:10:49,680
>> Absolutely.

232
00:10:49,680 --> 00:10:51,365
>> I have been there.

233
00:10:51,365 --> 00:10:56,200
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right now, I know on most of these

234
00:10:56,200 --> 00:11:01,365
they say 25 to 30%, but this next one,
it's pretty much guaranteed to be 30%.

235
00:11:01,365 --> 00:11:05,415
The virtualization push
is huge at Microsoft.

236
00:11:05,415 --> 00:11:08,465
And I'm not just talking about HyperV,
but Windows Azure also,

237
00:11:08,465 --> 00:11:11,970
which is built on HyperV, so
I guess it's kind of the same, but,

238
00:11:11,970 --> 00:11:17,160
they pretty much expect every environment
to use virtualization tools now.

239
00:11:17,160 --> 00:11:19,720
So we've got a big section on it, and

240
00:11:19,720 --> 00:11:23,300
this'll actually make up a decent part
of our show because it is so important.

241
00:11:24,510 --> 00:11:27,290
But you'll see in here we've got
a plan for our virtualization host.

242
00:11:27,290 --> 00:11:28,770
That's the physical machines.

243
00:11:28,770 --> 00:11:30,190
We got a plan for our virtual machines.

244
00:11:30,190 --> 00:11:32,920
The VM's.
We'll take a look at networking and

245
00:11:32,920 --> 00:11:37,380
storage under virtualization and
design considerations and plans.

246
00:11:37,380 --> 00:11:40,030
Notice how a lot of these say plan and
implement.

247
00:11:40,030 --> 00:11:43,130
The plan side,
we've gotta come up with our design.

248
00:11:43,130 --> 00:11:43,880
We gotta plan and

249
00:11:43,880 --> 00:11:47,440
figure out exactly what we need to provide
our network the resources it needs.

250
00:11:47,440 --> 00:11:50,740
But the implement side,
we've usually already learned.

251
00:11:50,740 --> 00:11:54,100
On the implement side, we've already
learned how to implement HyperV.

252
00:11:54,100 --> 00:11:55,460
We already know how to bring up VMs.

253
00:11:55,460 --> 00:11:56,910
That's not new.

254
00:11:56,910 --> 00:12:00,490
So what we're adding on are some
of the System Center Utilities.

255
00:12:00,490 --> 00:12:03,100
Things like
the System Center Virtual Machine Manager.

256
00:12:03,100 --> 00:12:04,100
SCVMM.

257
00:12:04,100 --> 00:12:05,810
And so we'll see some additional things.

258
00:12:05,810 --> 00:12:07,660
Yeah, right here.
Virtual Machine Manager.

259
00:12:07,660 --> 00:12:11,100
So we'll see bringing system center
into the mix to implement these.

260
00:12:11,100 --> 00:12:14,450
Whereas before we might have
done it directly in HyperV.

261
00:12:14,450 --> 00:12:15,350
And that's essential.

262
00:12:15,350 --> 00:12:16,950
The larger your data center gets,

263
00:12:16,950 --> 00:12:20,610
the less practical it is to manage
things on an individual server basis.

264
00:12:22,690 --> 00:12:26,750
And our last section is design and
implement identity and access solutions.

265
00:12:26,750 --> 00:12:27,770
>> Mm.
>> Mike, this is your favorite section.

266
00:12:27,770 --> 00:12:28,990
>> Oh yeah, we love this stuff.

267
00:12:28,990 --> 00:12:30,080
Certificate services.

268
00:12:30,080 --> 00:12:30,780
Love those.

269
00:12:30,780 --> 00:12:32,500
We get to dive into that.

270
00:12:32,500 --> 00:12:33,700
Setting up the whole hierarchy.

271
00:12:33,700 --> 00:12:37,700
It's not just setting up a certificate
server, but planning for that the root and

272
00:12:37,700 --> 00:12:40,950
then your subordinates and
deciding how you want to play that out.

273
00:12:40,950 --> 00:12:43,570
Are you doing different subordinates for
different locations or

274
00:12:43,570 --> 00:12:45,790
different purposes and things like that?

275
00:12:45,790 --> 00:12:49,450
And I think we'll end up tying into
managing the certificates themselves and

276
00:12:49,450 --> 00:12:52,740
then extending our authentication
beyond our boundaries.

277
00:12:52,740 --> 00:12:55,260
Taking it out into the cloud or
with extranets.

278
00:12:55,260 --> 00:12:59,030
Our business partners doing,
our federation identity solution.

279
00:12:59,030 --> 00:13:01,590
We'll take a peak at how
we set that up either

280
00:13:01,590 --> 00:13:03,170
with a business partner or Microsoft.

281
00:13:03,170 --> 00:13:07,060
Microsoft provides that federation
services that we can tie into there.

282
00:13:07,060 --> 00:13:10,930
Then getting into RMS and
everybody uses RMS right Don?

283
00:13:10,930 --> 00:13:12,150
Oh yeah.
Absolutely.

284
00:13:12,150 --> 00:13:13,545
It's widely deployed.

285
00:13:13,545 --> 00:13:15,880
[LAUGH]
>> We make fun of it.

286
00:13:15,880 --> 00:13:20,800
The right's management service, it's
>> It is good because we've talked

287
00:13:20,800 --> 00:13:23,720
a little bit about it before, but
it does give you the ability to take those

288
00:13:23,720 --> 00:13:28,510
permissions and tie them to the document
itself, not to the file system.

289
00:13:28,510 --> 00:13:33,330
So we can extend our control over those
resources beyond our boundaries and

290
00:13:33,330 --> 00:13:34,920
beyond our file systems.

291
00:13:34,920 --> 00:13:36,870
>> It does have a good place in it.

292
00:13:36,870 --> 00:13:38,990
>> Yeah.
If you're an all Microsoft shop,

293
00:13:38,990 --> 00:13:42,940
RMS is a great way to do
digital rights management, DRM.

294
00:13:42,940 --> 00:13:44,130
Right?

295
00:13:44,130 --> 00:13:47,850
But if you've got users that are external
to your organization there's a good bit of

296
00:13:47,850 --> 00:13:49,360
planning that has to go into that.

297
00:13:49,360 --> 00:13:52,770
And if you're not a Microsoft shop,
if you have a mixture of platforms,

298
00:13:52,770 --> 00:13:54,340
there's a lot of planning
that has to go in there.

299
00:13:54,340 --> 00:13:58,640
So So we kinda tackled that, but this last
section here, they do downplay a bit,

300
00:13:58,640 --> 00:14:02,470
see how they say 20%- 25%, so a smaller
portion of the exam comes from there, but

301
00:14:02,470 --> 00:14:06,350
it is important, it's good information
to know, especially if you're gonna be

302
00:14:06,350 --> 00:14:10,810
extending your data center into the cloud,
into Windows Azure or

303
00:14:10,810 --> 00:14:14,320
whatever, you'll want to be able
to link credentials between those.

304
00:14:14,320 --> 00:14:17,890
And that's the type of stuff
that we'll tackle down there.

305
00:14:17,890 --> 00:14:22,500
So those are the overall objectives that's
gonna be covered in this certification.

306
00:14:22,500 --> 00:14:25,340
Even if you're not seeking
the certification a lot of this is good

307
00:14:25,340 --> 00:14:26,840
knowledge to have.

308
00:14:26,840 --> 00:14:27,520
But I will say this.

309
00:14:27,520 --> 00:14:30,880
If you're just getting
started in IT the MCSE is

310
00:14:30,880 --> 00:14:33,070
not the certification
you should be seeking.

311
00:14:33,070 --> 00:14:37,450
The MCSE is designed for
people who have been in the field for

312
00:14:37,450 --> 00:14:39,150
many years at this point.

313
00:14:39,150 --> 00:14:41,200
That have already implemented
the technologies,

314
00:14:41,200 --> 00:14:43,730
they already understand the how's and
so on, and

315
00:14:43,730 --> 00:14:48,070
they've seen enough different environments
to start to understand the why's.

316
00:14:48,070 --> 00:14:52,850
So what we're really doing is applying
Microsoft's best practices to those why's

317
00:14:52,850 --> 00:14:55,850
and getting ready for
that more of a management position.

318
00:14:55,850 --> 00:14:57,160
So if you are,

319
00:14:57,160 --> 00:15:02,505
if you have a goal of becoming a system
admin manager or a network manager.

320
00:15:02,505 --> 00:15:04,300
>> Mm-hm.
>> Or something like that.

321
00:15:04,300 --> 00:15:07,910
That is the type of person that the MCSE
is really designed for and consultants.

322
00:15:07,910 --> 00:15:10,720
Right, people that are roaming
consultants, need to have these

323
00:15:10,720 --> 00:15:13,210
skills because you're dealing with so
many different environments.

324
00:15:13,210 --> 00:15:17,130
How do you make sure they are properly
set up and ready to grow in scale.

325
00:15:17,130 --> 00:15:20,410
You don't want a solution for today,
you need a solution that lasts for

326
00:15:20,410 --> 00:15:21,610
tomorrow and beyond.

327
00:15:22,920 --> 00:15:25,280
That sounds like marketing.

328
00:15:25,280 --> 00:15:27,160
Tomorrow and beyond.

329
00:15:27,160 --> 00:15:29,960
All right, so
definitely keep that in mind.

330
00:15:29,960 --> 00:15:32,690
The exam itself is a pretty
fair exam I think.

331
00:15:32,690 --> 00:15:35,340
Microsoft of all the exam
vendors out there.

332
00:15:35,340 --> 00:15:38,276
Microsoft has one of
the best grammar checkers.

333
00:15:38,276 --> 00:15:38,857
>> Right.

334
00:15:38,857 --> 00:15:42,290
>> I know I get so frustrated
sometimes at the other vendors when,

335
00:15:42,290 --> 00:15:45,080
you read the question and
you're like, this makes no sense,

336
00:15:45,080 --> 00:15:47,290
it doesn't matter if I know
the technology or not.

337
00:15:47,290 --> 00:15:50,220
I just can't decipher what
this person is saying.

338
00:15:50,220 --> 00:15:53,100
And Microsoft is really good about that.

339
00:15:53,100 --> 00:15:57,180
You will see though,
because this is a design exam.

340
00:15:57,180 --> 00:15:59,325
That there will often times be
more than one right answer.

341
00:15:59,325 --> 00:16:00,320
>> Mm-hm.

342
00:16:00,320 --> 00:16:05,670
>> If they're asking you to select the
appropriate design model for a solution,

343
00:16:05,670 --> 00:16:08,990
it's not uncommon that all of the design
models they recommend would work.

344
00:16:08,990 --> 00:16:11,260
>> Right.
>> That everyone of them would work.

345
00:16:11,260 --> 00:16:14,890
But one of them will best
match the scenario, right?

346
00:16:14,890 --> 00:16:19,140
That client's needs or future expansion or
least administrative effort,

347
00:16:19,140 --> 00:16:20,830
whatever it is that they're asking for.

348
00:16:20,830 --> 00:16:22,410
So, be ready for that.

349
00:16:22,410 --> 00:16:27,080
These are a little bit more, I don't want
to call them subjective, you know, but

350
00:16:27,080 --> 00:16:30,870
they do require a little bit of
independent thought to make sure you pick

351
00:16:30,870 --> 00:16:33,290
the best answer cell.

352
00:16:33,290 --> 00:16:38,030
I know for me, on this exam, the old mark
for review button, I'd probably use that

353
00:16:38,030 --> 00:16:41,810
more than any other exam, just because
there's different ways to do things.

354
00:16:43,170 --> 00:16:48,000
All right, but all that being said,
it's a pretty exciting certification.

355
00:16:48,000 --> 00:16:52,350
It's a nice change from the 413 which
was very design heavy, you know.

356
00:16:52,350 --> 00:16:55,500
This one we get into a lot of design,
but we're seeing some new stuff,

357
00:16:55,500 --> 00:16:58,150
we're seeing the system centered tools and
that's a lot of fun.

358
00:16:59,382 --> 00:17:02,650
All right, so Mike can you think of
anything we have left off here for

359
00:17:02,650 --> 00:17:03,280
our review?

360
00:17:03,280 --> 00:17:07,134
>> No I think we covered it all,
we talked about the objectives and

361
00:17:07,134 --> 00:17:08,747
the track that we're on.

362
00:17:08,747 --> 00:17:10,572
>> That's basically it.

363
00:17:10,572 --> 00:17:14,530
All right, well, ladies and gentlemen,
if that stuff sounds exciting to you, and

364
00:17:14,530 --> 00:17:17,100
that's what you want to learn,
they you are in the right place.

365
00:17:17,100 --> 00:17:20,810
This was just our little overview to
introduce you to the certification, but

366
00:17:20,810 --> 00:17:24,121
stay tuned because we have episodes
covering the actual exam content

367
00:17:24,121 --> 00:17:24,704
coming up.

368
00:17:24,704 --> 00:17:31,290
I hope to see you then.

369
00:17:31,290 --> 00:17:33,259
[SOUND]

topics.title: Manage and maintain a server infrastructure
Plan and implement a highly available enterprise infrastructure
Plan and implement a server virtualization infrastructure

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike describe and demonstrate what it takes to design and implement a Certificate Authority(CA) Infrastructure. They start by looking at the hierarchical tiers when using an offline root CA. Then they explore Certificate Enrollment Web Services and Certificate Enrollment Policy Web Services. Finally, they describe Network Device Enrollment Services.
episodes.title: Design a CA Infrastructure

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their discussion of designing and implementing a Certificate Authority(CA) Infrastructure. Here they demonstrate the process of certificate validation and revocation. Finally, they look at backing up and restoring the CA database and private key in a Disaster Recovery situation.
episodes.title: Design a CA Infrastructure Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue the discussion of CA infrastructure by moving into the installing the CA role and bringing the root CA online. They also show how to configure the certification revocation list distribution point commonly known as the CDP as well as configuring the authority information access.
episodes.title: Design a CA Infrastructure Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue the discussion of CA infrastructure by moving into the installing the CA role and bringing the the subordinate certificate authority online. They also look at how to import that root CA certificate on the subordinate CA, completing the certificate signing request as well as installing the subordinate CA certificate. Finally, they will demonstrate how to deploy the root CA certificate through ADDS.
episodes.title: Design a CA Infrastructure Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike talk about concepts surrounding the implementation and management of certification within a CA infrastructure. They look at the different schema types for certificate templates and server compatibility.
episodes.title: Implement and Manage Certificates

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their discussion on concepts surrounding the implementation and management of certification within a CA infrastructure. They talk about auto enrollment , superseding certificates, multipurpose certifications and adding purposes through extensions. Finally they will look at setting up a EFS recovery agent.
episodes.title: Implement and Manage Certificates Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their discussion on concepts surrounding the implementation and management of certification within a CA infrastructure. They move through EFS recovery agents then into key recovery agents or KRAâ€™s as well as the process of setting up a KRAâ€™s and demonstrate key archival and recovery.
episodes.title: Implement and Manage Certificates Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam take you through implementing Federated Identity services. Here they start by discussing the planning steps for standing up an ADFS server, a Federation Server Proxy, and High Availability(HA). They also discuss the other key components like Federation Server Certificates and Federation Server Farms.
episodes.title: Implementing Federated Identity

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue discussing components and steps for implementing Federated Identity Services. They pick back up by talking about integrating with Online Services, Azure, and Office365. They also explore configuring ADFS Claims Providers and Attribute Stores.
episodes.title: Implementing Federated Identity Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue discussing components and steps for implementing Federated Identity Services. Here they round out their overview of topics by discussing Claims Provider Trust components, creating Claims Rules, designing Claims types, and implementing Web Application Proxy.
episodes.title: Implementing Federated Identity Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam take all the previously discussed concepts and use them to actually stand up Active Directory Federated Identity Services. Here they take you step-by-step through the process, discussing each component in detail so that you are properly equipped to perform an ADFS implementation.
episodes.title: Implementing Federated Identity Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam take all the previously discussed concepts and use them to actually stand up Active Directory Federated Identity Services. Here they take you step-by-step through the process, discussing each component in detail so that you are properly equipped to perform an ADFS implementation.
episodes.title: Implementing Federated Identity Part 5

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam introduce you to Dynamic Access Control. Here they will discuss and demonstrate planning and implementing data access for users and devices. They go over each of the building blocks and vocabulary, prerequisites for setting up DAC, and then demo an actual DAC implementation.
episodes.title: Dynamic Access Control

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam overview the concepts and components for implementing Rights Management. Here they discuss the AD-RMS workflow steps and major AD-RMS components, specifically Clusters, Root-certification servers, and Licensing servers.
episodes.title: Implementing Rights Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam overview the concepts and components for implementing Rights Management. They pick back up by exploring the steps for planning and implementing an AD-RMS Cluster. Then, they look at configuring High Availability(HA) and Sizing.
episodes.title: Implementing Rights Management Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam overview the concepts and components for implementing Rights Management. Topics discussed here include Backup and Recovery strategies, decommissioning/removing AD-RMS, upgrading/migrating, and RMS Templates and Template distribution.
episodes.title: Implementing Rights Management Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam overview the concepts and components for implementing Rights Management. Topics discussed here include options for configuring AD-RMS Exclusion Policies, planning the AD-RMS Super-Users group, integration with Sharepoint, integration with ADFS, and AD-RMS with Azure.
episodes.title: Implementing Rights Management Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam start their demonstration of configuring Active Directory Rights Management Services. Here they will take all the concepts that you've been learning and walk you through the setup involved in standing up a AD-RMS system.
episodes.title: Configuring AD-RMS

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue their demonstration of configuring Active Directory Rights Management Services. Here they will take all the concepts that you've been learning and walk you through the setup involved in standing up a AD-RMS system.
episodes.title: Configuring AD-RMS Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue their demonstration of configuring Active Directory Rights Management Services. Here they will take all the concepts that you've been learning and walk you through the setup involved in standing up a AD-RMS system.
episodes.title: Configuring AD-RMS Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam finish their demonstration of configuring Active Directory Rights Management Services. Here they will take all the concepts that you've been learning and walk you through the setup involved in standing up a AD-RMS system.
episodes.title: Configuring AD-RMS Part 4

topics.title: Design and implement identity and access solutions
